Award.AwardTitle: p-adic automorphic forms, p-adic L-functions, and Selmer groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project in number theory studies arithmetic properties of automorphic forms, which are functions that satisfy certain transformation properties. More specifically, the project is to study divisibility properties of these mathematical objects by high powers of a given prime number. The study of these properties has yielded significant advances in number theory in the past few years: a proof Fermat's Last Theorem, a proof the Sato-Tate conjecture, and a proof of the Iwasawa main conjecture for elliptic curves. The work resulting from this project will give more insight into some of the current most important problems in number theory. This project will enhance our knowledge of the deep relationships between p-adic automorphic forms, Galois representations, and their p-adic L functions -- a central focus of number theory -- as well as have significant consequences for our understanding of mathematics in general. The project will involve the training of graduate students.

The domain of research of this project is the arithmetic of p-adic automorphic forms, their Galois representations, and L-functions. This project is a continuation of the PI's work related to the construction and the study of congruences between automorphic forms of various weights and levels and their links with p-adic L-functions and Selmer groups. The project will continue to build some of the foundations of the general theory of the p-adic automorphic forms and p-adic Eisenstein series with an eye one the important applications that will result. In particular, this theory applied to the case of unitary and symplectic groups will have important applications to the so-called p-adic Bloch-Kato conjecture and Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture. Studying the dimension of irreducible components of eigenvarieties, p-adic deformations of nearly over-convergent automorphic forms, critical p-adic L-functions, p-adic interpolation of automorphic periods, construction of p-adic measures attached to L-functions and Eisenstein series, p-adic Euler systems, and Kolyvagin systems and their link with p-adic L-functions are some of the topics that will be dealt with in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urban has been working during this project on several topics partly  in collaboration with his students or with J. Tilouine or just by himself. This work has led to discoveries on several research fronts, the training of his students who are now holding academic positions, and to the dissemination of his progresses and results through writings and lectures at international conferences.

The main topic that Urban has worked on is his construction of Euler systems using Eisenstein congruences for which he has discovered the optimal construction in the GL(1) case. Several unexpected obstacles has slowed down his progress but eventually the correct definition has been reached. The main remaining difficulty is to prove that the constructed norm compatible system of Galois cohomolgy classes is integral. Urban shows that this integrality statement is a consequence of the main Iwasawa conjecture, proving by this way that the construction is actually correct. Lately, Urban has observed that a modification of his construction can lead to an independent proof of the integrality of these classes through the use of results on the p-adic Langlands correspondence. In collaboration with Tilouine, Urban has also proved an integral period relation for quadratic base change for GL(2) that was conjectured by Hida. One consequence is that it provides a proof of the Bloch-Kato conjecture for the Selmer group of an adjoint modular Galois representations twisted by a real quadratic character, a result that was still open until now. In the imaginary quadratic case, they have also formulated an integral version of a conjecture of Prasanna-Venkatesh that involves the cotangent complex of the Hecke algebra which is a totaly new invariant that has been suspected to be important for some time by the experts.

The PI has also advises his students on the constructions of p-adic L-functions and p-adic nearly overconvergent forms for  general symplectic groups (Zheng Liu), on extended Eigenvarieties (Daniel Gulotta) and p-adic L-function interpolating non-critical values (Pak-Hin Lee).These three works have lead these student to get academic position in the US, Canada and UK.

The Urban has also participated to many international conferences and workshop on the three continents to disseminate his work and ideas on the previous topics. He has also taught graduate courses on them at his home institution.
